They don't have unrounded finals yet. The star for preliminary numbers is gone is gone because they're not using preliminary numbers, but they won't have unrounded finals until early next week at which point they will update their chart; until then their chart will read _._0 because they're listing two decimal places without controlling for significant figures. It's a quirk in their charts that I've noticed after following them for a while.
If you don't believe me, look at how *every* new broadcast show from this Monday is currently listed as _._0 by tvseriesfinale:
* [The Voice](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/the-voice-season-12-ratings-mondays/) * [Taken](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/taken-season-one-ratings/) * [Dancing With The Stars](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/dancing-stars-season-24-ratings-spring-2017/) * [Quantico](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/quantico-season-two-ratings/) * [Superior Donuts](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/superior-donuts-season-one-ratings/) * [24 :Legacy](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/24-legacy-season-one-ratings/) * [APB](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/apb-season-one-ratings/) * [Jane The Virgin](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/jane-virgin-season-three-ratings/)

Shes a main ~~recurring~~ cast member for Arrow (Season 6)
As Black Siren, who is still alive, so that doesn't require any rewriting of history.

We don't know that the final was a 0.70, just that it rounded to a 0.7. Unrounded finals won't be available until early next week (tvseriesfinale will list _._0 initially but they'll update it when they get unroundeds).

I'm just going with what the CW gave as their expectations for Supergirl, which was for it two be in their top two shows. It is currently meeting that expectation. Ratings are down across the entire network, but that's not an issue specific to Supergirl and we don't know how much lost revenue from lower ratings is being made up by stuff like the CW app. As for budgets, we don't have hard numbers for those so it's hard to quantitatively account for that (also the only CW shows getting 0.5s or higher are the superhero shows and Supernatural).

Now its doing worse than the Flash.
But better than every other CW show. The CW said they expected it to be one of their top two shows, and it is (and I doubt they expected it to do better than the Flash seeing as both had similar ratings at the end of last season and Flash was already on the CW).

By "particularly in the spring" I meant anytime from February through May. Again, go and actually look at the air dates for old shows: they went on breaks all the time, and it was no more predictable than now.
For example, here's how some well-known TV shows were scheduled in the spring exactly 20 years ago:
* [ER](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ER_episodes#Season_3_.281996.E2.80.9397.29): on break for Feb 27, March 6, March 13, March 20, March 27, April 3 * [Seinfeld](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Seinfeld_episodes#Season_8_.281996.E2.80.931997.29): on break for Jan 23, Feb 27, March 6, March 20, March 27, April 3, April 17 * [Friends](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Friends_episodes#Season_3_.281996.E2.80.9397.29): on break for Jan 23, Feb 27, March 20, April 10 * [Frasier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Frasier_episodes#Season_4_.281996.E2.80.9397.29): on break for Jan 28, Feb 4, March 4, March 18, March 25, April 8 * [Law Order](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Law_%26_Order_episodes#Season_7:_1996.E2.80.9397): on break for Jan 22, Jan 29, March 6, April 9, April 23, * [The X-Files](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_The_X-Files_episodes#Season_4_.281996.E2.80.9397.29): on break for Jan 19, March 2, March 9, March 30, April 6 * [Roseanne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Roseanne_episodes#Season_9_.281996.E2.80.9397.29): on break for Jan 21, Feb 4, March 11, March 25, April 1, April 8, April 15, April 22, April 29, May 6 * [Star Trek: Voyager](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Star_Trek:_Voyager_episodes#Season_3_.281996.E2.80.9397.29): on break for Jan 22, March 5, March 12, March 26, April 2, April 16 * [Home Improvement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Home_Improvement_episodes#Season_6_.281996.E2.80.931997.29): on break for Jan 21, Feb 4, March 4, March 18, March 25, April 8, April 22
That's a lot of breaks, and no less random than the ones shows take these days.

20 years ago shows generally ran straight through the current half-season once they started. Shows didn't randomly take a week off here, a month off there
Sure they did. Go and look at episode lists from back then and you'll see that shows often had breaks (that weren't the winter holidays), particularly in the spring. Broadcast TV schedules have run from September to May for many decades, and the only way to stretch ~22-25 episodes over that time is with breaks (and the single several-month break that some shows do these days is a relatively modern phenomenon).
unless the network was actively trying to kill the show by sabotaging its ratings
Why do you think networks would try to actively sabotage the ratings of their own shows? If networks are sufficiently unhappy with a show's performance they don't need to 'try to kill it' they just pull it from the schedule and replace it (then possibly burn it off later on weekends and/or the summer); leaving it on the schedule but deliberately trying to hurt its ratings would be moronic.

This age of completely disjointed TV show seasons
The past 40+ years?

Would they go 17-1 in a power conference?
Probably not, but then in a power conference they wouldn't necessarily need to go 17-1 to get a 1-seed, so that's not a great comparison.
